CN V can be injured by a lateral pontine lesion. Injury to this nerve can also occur because of compression by a superior cerebellar artery aneurysm.
questions.hint: The findings from this patient's radiological imaging indicate a transtentorial uncal herniation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy and weakness for the past 5 days. During this period, she has had a headache that worsens when she leans forward or lies down. Her arms and face have appeared swollen over the past 2 weeks. She has a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast. She underwent radical amputation of the left breast followed by radiation therapy 4 years ago. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Examination shows jugular venous distention, a mastectomy scar over the left thorax, and engorged veins on the anterior chest wall. There is 1+ pitting edema in both arms. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While Hodgkin lymphomas frequently manifest with mediastinal lymphadenopathy, compression of the SVC resulting in SVC syndrome is rare. Non-Hodgkin lymphomas, on the other hand, are responsible for the majority of cases of SVC syndrome in young patients. This patient lacks any typical symptoms of lymphoma (painless lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, or B symptoms), which makes a malignant lymphoma unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's history of breast cancer, chronic smoking, and tamoxifen therapy increases the risk of a hypercoagulable state and the development of a pulmonary embolism (PE). PE may cause right heart failure (i.e., jugular venous distension, hypotension, tachycardia) but not selective facial and upper limb edema. In addition, and in contrast to this patient's features, PE manifests with respiratory distress, cough, and rales on pulmonary auscultation.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy is a predisposing factor for the development of constrictive pericarditis, which may be the underlying cause of this patient's jugular venous distension and peripheral edema. However, patients with constrictive pericarditis typically have a thickened myocardium and a pericardial knock on auscultation, which is not heard here. Additionally, the peripheral edema in constrictive pericarditis involves both the upper and lower extremities; the presence of a selective facial and upper limb edema in this patient suggests another etiology.

D) CORRECT:

SVC syndrome is most commonly caused by lung cancer (usually small cell lung cancer or squamous cell carcinoma) or non-Hodgkin lymphoma (particularly in younger patients). This patient's history of chronic smoking is a risk factor for lung cancer. Compression of the SVC by a tumor impairs the venous backflow to the right atrium, resulting in venous congestion in the head, neck, and upper extremities. Other nonmalignant causes of SVC syndrome include mediastinal fibrosis, tuberculosis, histoplasmosis, or thrombosis of the SVC due to the placement of a central venous device. A CT scan of the chest should be obtained in this patient to evaluate for malignancy.
Image Description:

Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome is caused by obstruction of the SVC (e.g., due to malignancy or intraluminal thrombosis), resulting in impaired blood flow from the SVC into the right atrium. As a consequence, drainage occurs increasingly into the inferior vena cava via collateral veins, resulting in a prominent venous patterning on the upper body. Venous congestion proximally to the obstruction results in edema of the upper extremities, neck, and face.

SVC syndrome can become life-threatening if cerebral edema (leading to increased intracranial pressure) or laryngeal edema develop.

E) INCORRECT:

Nephrotic syndrome causes renal filtration dysfunction and is characterized by marked edema, weight gain, hypertension, and a hypercoagulable state. This patient has a selective facial and upper limb edema, which is not characteristic of the edema pattern seen in nephrotic syndrome (initially a periorbital and later general edema). Additionally, nephrotic syndrome does not explain this patient's JVD, tachycardia, and hypotension.
questions.hint: Headache that worsens when leaning forward, engorged veins over the anterior chest, and swelling limited to the head, neck, and upper extremities are consistent with superior vena cava syndrome (SVC syndrome).

questions.text: You are caring for a 26-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by ambulance following a motor vehicle collision. He does not open his eyes to command or respond to verbal cues. A CT scan of the head reveals a hyperdense fluid collection in the right medial temporal lobe with medial and downward displacement of the uncus. Which one of the following cranial nerves is most likely to be injured as a result of this lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The facial nerve (CN VII) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VII is in close proximity to the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and it can be injured by bleeds or aneurysms of this vessel.

B) CORRECT:

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is most likely to be injured by uncal herniation, which manifests with an abducted and depressed ipsilateral eye (due to damage to motor fibers that innervate most of the extraocular eye muscles) with a fixed, dilated pupil (due to damage to parasympathetic fibers). Other features of uncal herniation include cortical blindness with contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing due to compression of the posterior cerebral artery, and Kernohan phenomenon due to compression of the contralateral cerebral peduncle. A downward shift of the brainstem causes hemorrhages and compression of the reticular formation, which can lead to impaired consciousness and, ultimately, death.

A CN III injury can also be caused by an aneurysm or bleed of the posterior communicating artery or posterior cerebral artery, both of which are in close proximity to this nerve.

Key learning point: Transtentorial uncal herniation most commonly compresses the oculomotor nerve (CN III), leading to a fixed, dilated pupil and impaired eye movements.
Image Description:

Brain herniations occur as a result of increased intracranial pressure, such as that caused by subdural hematomas. Variations include herniation of brain tissue under the falx cerebri (1), below the tentorium cerebelli (2, 3), downwards through the foramen magnum (4), above the tentorium cerebelli (5), or outside of the skull (6).

C) INCORRECT:

The abducens nerve (CN VI) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VI is local to the basilar artery, and it can be injured by a basilar artery aneurysm.

D) INCORRECT:

The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VIII is in close proximity to the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and it can be injured by bleeds or aneurysms of this vessel.

E) INCORRECT:

The trigeminal nerve (CN V) exits the brainstem at the pons, which is situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN V can be injured by a lateral pontine lesion. Injury to this nerve can also occur because of compression by a superior cerebellar artery aneurysm.
questions.hint: The findings from this patient's radiological imaging indicate a transtentorial uncal herniation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with a history of hypertension presents with progressive headache over 2 days, confusion, and vomiting. The patient appears lethargic with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 12. Vital signs are BP, 180/100; P, 58; R, 8–12 irregular pattern; oxygen saturation, 89% on room air. The only abnormal CT head finding is shown. Which initial step in management should be prioritized?

choices.text: Supplemental oxygen and head of bed elevation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the patient is vomiting and there is some concern for airway protection, intubation of patients with elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) requires careful consideration of the risks and benefits. Patients with high ICP should not undergo rapid sequence intubation without appropriate pretreatment, as laryngeal manipulation can significantly raise ICP and worsen the clinical condition.

B) INCORRECT:

The CT shows dilated ventricles, indicating acute hydrocephalus. Dexamethasone is only indicated for elevated intracranial pressure caused by vasogenic edema secondary to CNS infection, inflammation, or neoplasms. It is not indicated for acute hydrocephalus without an underlying inflammatory or neoplastic process.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in patients with acute hydrocephalus with elevated intracranial pressure due to the risk of precipitating brain herniation. The dilated ventricles on CT indicate obstructive hydrocephalus requiring neurosurgical intervention.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – The CT shows dilated ventricles consistent with acute hydrocephalus, and this patient has clinical features of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP). This patient has significant hypoxia requiring immediate supplemental oxygen to prevent secondary brain injury. Head of bed elevation to approximately 30° can reduce ICP without compromising cerebral blood flow. Safe temporizing measures for ICP management are indicated while expediting definitive neurosurgical CSF drainage (e.g., external ventricular drain placement or ventriculoperitoneal shunting).

E) INCORRECT:

The CT shows dilated ventricles, and this patient has clinical features of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP). Aggressive antihypertensive therapy could compromise cerebral perfusion pressure in a patient with elevated ICP. Blood pressure management requires careful consideration of the relationship between systemic blood pressure and ICP.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents after a high-speed motor vehicle collision with altered mental status. Her vital signs are BP, 80/50; P, 115; R, 32; oxygen saturation 92% on room air. She has no obvious external bleeding. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Neurological examination shows spontaneous eye opening, inappropriate verbal responses, and withdrawal to painful stimuli. Arterial blood gas shows pH 7.35, PaCO2 48 mmHg, PaO2 65 mmHg. CT head is pending. What is the most appropriate initial intervention to prevent secondary brain injury?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intubation is not currently indicated in this patient with suspected traumatic brain injury (TBI) as the GCS is 11 and the airway is patent. Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) induction agents could worsen hypotension, further compromising cerebral perfusion. Controlled hyperventilation to PaCO2 30–35 mm Hg should only be used as a short-term temporizing measure (i.e., for 30 minutes) in patients with signs of increased ICP or cerebral herniation syndromes, which this patient does not have. Hyperventilation otherwise causes cerebral vasoconstriction and decreased cerebral blood flow, worsening secondary brain injury through ischemia to uninjured tissue via the inverse steal phenomenon. If indications of RSI arise due to neurological deterioration or cerebral herniation, a cautious approach to intubation of patients with high ICP is required, as laryngoscopy can worsen high ICP.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's MAP of 60 mmHg is below the 65 mmHg threshold needed for adequate cerebral perfusion pressure. Hypotension decreases cerebral blood flow and worsens neurological outcomes in patients with depressed consciousness. Brain injury disrupts cerebral autoregulation, making cerebral blood flow dependent on cerebral perfusion pressure. Isotonic saline prevents cerebral edema while restoring perfusion.

C) INCORRECT:

The patient's current SpO2 of 92% is already within the acceptable range for normoxia (target SpO2 > 92-94%) to prevent secondary brain injury. Targeting SpO2 > 99% would create hyperoxia, which can cause cerebral vasoconstriction and cerebral ischemia, worsening neurological outcomes. Supplemental oxygen would also not address the factor most likely to affect this patient's cerebral perfusion pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Mannitol treats confirmed increased intracranial pressure (ICP). This patient's normal and reactive pupils are inconsistent with elevated ICP or cerebral herniation syndromes. Administering osmotic therapy without confirming high ICP (e.g., via imaging or consistent clinical features) could be dangerous, especially since this could worsen this patient's hypotension, which can further compromise cerebral perfusion pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

Therapeutic hypothermia is not indicated for traumatic brain injury as part of routine neuroprotective measures. The goal of temperature management in secondary brain injury prevention is normothermia, not hypothermia.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with a 2-week history of worsening morning headaches and intermittent episodes of word-finding difficulty. His spouse reports he has been increasingly irritable and forgetful. Examination shows mild papilledema, left facial droop, left-sided weakness, and mild dysphasia. Vital signs are normal. CT head is shown. Neurosurgery has been consulted. What is the most appropriate interim management?

choices.text: Perform lumbar puncture and CSF analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in patients with suspected brain tumors and signs of increased intracranial pressure due to the risk of cerebral herniation. This patient's neuroimaging already demonstrates a mass lesion with surrounding edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary seizure prophylaxis with levetiracetam is not recommended for brain tumors. The patient has not experienced seizures, and prophylactic antiepileptic drugs are not supported by evidence for preventing brain tumor-associated seizures.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – The patient has clear signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), including papilledema, morning headaches, and imaging showing vasogenic cerebral edema with mass effect. Glucocorticoids such as dexamethasone are indicated for patients with signs of elevated ICP and cerebral edema to reduce brain swelling. While hyperosmolar therapies for ICP management, like mannitol, are also appropriate for elevated ICP, dexamethasone is the preferred initial intervention for tumor-related cerebral edema.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's CT already establishes the diagnosis of a brain tumor with vasogenic cerebral edema. While gadolinium-enhanced MRI will eventually be needed for better tumor characterization, the immediate priority is medical management of elevated intracranial pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

Therapeutic hyperventilation is usually reserved for patients with severe increased intracranial pressure (ICP) or impending herniation refractory to medical therapies, as a temporizing measure while awaiting surgical treatment. In this conscious patient, hyperosmolar therapies for ICP management or other targeted medication for vasogenic cerebral edema would be more appropriate initial therapy

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of malignant brain tumor presents with progressively worsening headache and confusion over the past 2 days. Vital signs are BP, 190/55; P, 52; R, 10; T, normal. On examination, he has a Glasgow coma scale score of 12 and bilateral papilledema. CT of the head shows a large mass lesion with significant midline shift. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Urgent neurosurgical consultation is the most appropriate next step. This patient has clinical and radiographic evidence of elevated intracranial pressure with a resectable lesion causing mass effect and midline shift. Emergency surgical intervention may be required to prevent brain herniation and death.

B) INCORRECT:

While airway protection may be needed, intubation can increase intracranial pressure and should be performed by experienced personnel only when absolutely necessary. This patient's Glasgow coma scale score of 12 does not mandate immediate intubation.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in patients with elevated intracranial pressure and mass effect because the procedure can precipitate brain herniation. The midline shift on CT imaging makes this procedure dangerous.

D) INCORRECT:

While mannitol may be used as part of medical management for elevated intracranial pressure, emergency surgical evaluation takes priority if there is a resectable lesion causing significant mass effect. Medical therapy alone is insufficient for this patient's presentation.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI provides detailed imaging, but it is not appropriate in this unstable patient with elevated intracranial pressure. The CT already shows the critical finding of mass effect with midline shift, and further imaging would delay definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with worsening headache and confusion over the past 2 hours. The patient was involved in a fall from a ladder earlier today. On examination, the patient is confused, opens eyes to voice, and withdraws to pain. Vital signs are BP, 170/95; P, 48; R, 8 with irregular pattern. CT head shows a left-sided acute subdural hematoma with 12-mm midline shift and compressed basal cisterns. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Secure airway with endotracheal intubation and immediate neurosurgical consultation
Obtain arterial blood gas and serum osmolarity
Elevate head of bed to 30° and administer sedation
Initiate controlled hyperventilation to PaCO2 of 30 mm Hg

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score of 8 with signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) and Cushing triad. The stepwise approach to elevated ICP begins with ABCDE resuscitation, requiring emergency airway management for GCS ≤ 8. Early neurosurgical consultation is essential for this evacuable hematoma with significant mass effect.

B) INCORRECT:

Laboratory tests may provide supportive information but should not delay urgent clinical interventions in a patient with a Glasgow coma scale score of 8 and signs of elevated intracranial pressure. The clinical presentation and imaging findings are sufficient to guide immediate management priorities.

C) INCORRECT:

Supportive measures for intracranial pressure management are important, but in a patient with decreased consciousness and abnormal breathing patterns, they must be implemented after another urgent clinical intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Temporizing measures such as controlled hyperventilation are reserved for specific clinical scenarios and are performed after other urgent clinical interventions.

E) INCORRECT:

Medical therapies to reduce intracranial pressure are part of a broader management plan, but they are not the immediate priority in this patient with severe neurological impairment.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive. His wife reports that he complained of a sudden severe headache and left-sided weakness 4 hours ago. He has a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation. On examination, he is stuporous and withdraws his right side to painful stimuli but has no movement on the left. His right pupil is 4 mm and reactive, while his left pupil is 6 mm and sluggishly reactive. His blood pressure is 190/105 mm Hg, heart rate is 52/min, and respirations are irregular at 8/min. A noncontrast head CT shows a large right middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke with significant cerebral edema and 8 mm of midline shift. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intervention to acutely lower this patient's intracranial pressure?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decompressive hemicraniectomy is a potentially life-saving surgical procedure for malignant cerebral edema following a large hemispheric stroke and is likely indicated for this patient. However, it is not the most appropriate initial intervention. An alternative management approach should be initiated immediately in the emergency department while a neurosurgical consultation is obtained and the patient is prepared for potential surgery.

B) CORRECT:

The most appropriate initial intervention is hyperosmolar therapy to rapidly lower intracranial pressure (ICP). Intravenous hypertonic saline (e.g., 3% saline) creates an osmotic gradient that draws water out of the edematous brain parenchyma and into the intravascular space, thereby reducing cerebral volume and ICP. This is a first-line, rapid-acting medical therapy for life-threatening cerebral edema. Mannitol is an alternative osmotic agent with a similar mechanism of action. These therapies serve as a bridge to more definitive interventions, such as decompressive surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperventilation lowers intracranial pressure (ICP) by causing cerebral vasoconstriction, which reduces cerebral blood volume. However, this vasoconstriction also reduces cerebral blood flow, which can exacerbate ischemia in the injured brain. Aggressive hyperventilation (partial pressure of arterial carbon dioxide < 30 mm Hg) is generally avoided. It may be used as a temporary, bridging measure for refractory ICP elevation, but it is not the preferred initial intervention due to the risk of worsening ischemic injury.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's severe hypertension is part of the Cushing triad, a physiological response to maintain cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) in the face of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP). Aggressively lowering the mean arterial pressure (MAP) without first addressing the high ICP can critically decrease CPP (CPP = MAP - ICP) and worsen ischemia in the penumbra of the stroke. Management of ICP is the primary priority over blood pressure control in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids, such as dexamethasone, are effective for reducing vasogenic edema associated with brain tumors or abscesses. However, they are ineffective and potentially harmful (e.g., by causing hyperglycemia, increasing infection risk) in cytotoxic edema, which is the primary pathophysiology of edema following an acute ischemic stroke. Therefore, steroids are contraindicated for managing cerebral edema from a stroke.
questions.hint: This patient has a large ischemic stroke causing significant cerebral edema, mass effect, and signs of uncal herniation (e.g., anisocoria, Cushing triad).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being struck in the head. He had a brief lucid interval before a rapid decline in consciousness. His Glasgow Coma Scale score is 7. Physical examination shows a 6-mm, nonreactive right pupil and left-sided hemiparesis. A CT scan of the head shows a right-sided epidural hematoma with transtentorial herniation of the uncus. The pupillary finding is most likely caused by compression of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The optic nerve (CN II) is responsible for the afferent limb of the pupillary light reflex, which senses light. While severe intracranial pressure can cause papilledema (swelling of the optic disc), direct compression of CN II by uncal herniation is not the primary mechanism for a fixed, dilated pupil. Injury to CN II would cause vision loss or an afferent pupillary defect, not a dilated, nonreactive pupil.

B) INCORRECT:

The abducens nerve (CN VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye. Its long intracranial course makes it vulnerable to stretching from generalized increases in intracranial pressure, which can cause a lateral gaze palsy. However, it has no role in pupillary function, and its compression does not cause a fixed, dilated pupil.

C) INCORRECT:

The trochlear nerve (CN IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for intorsion and depression of the eye. While it can be damaged in head trauma, leading to vertical diplopia, it has no motor function related to the pupil. Therefore, its compression would not cause the pupillary findings described.

D) INCORRECT:

The trigeminal nerve (CN V) is primarily responsible for facial sensation and motor control of the muscles of mastication. It does not have any function in controlling pupillary size or reactivity. While the ophthalmic division (V1) provides the afferent limb of the corneal reflex, it is not involved in the pupillary light reflex.

E) CORRECT:

As the uncus of the temporal lobe herniates through the tentorial notch, it compresses the ipsilateral oculomotor nerve (CN III). The parasympathetic fibers, which mediate pupillary constriction, run along the superficial aspect of CN III and are the first to be affected by this external compression. This leads to unopposed sympathetic stimulation, resulting in a fixed and dilated pupil on the same side as the lesion. This finding is a critical neurologic emergency indicating impending brainstem compression.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation is typical of an epidural hematoma causing increased intracranial pressure and subsequent uncal herniation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 6-week history of a progressively worsening headache. She describes the headache as diffuse, throbbing, and most severe upon waking in the morning. It is often associated with nausea and brief episodes of blurred vision, especially when she stands up quickly. Her medical history is significant for obesity. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows a mild lateral gaze palsy of the right eye. A funduscopic examination is performed. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed?

choices.text: Blurring of the optic disc margins
A pale retina with a cherry-red spot

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Elevated cerebrospinal fluid pressure is transmitted along the optic nerve sheath, causing bilateral swelling of the optic nerve heads, known as papilledema. The earliest and most characteristic sign of papilledema is the blurring of the optic disc margins, often starting superiorly and inferiorly. Other findings include disc hyperemia, loss of spontaneous venous pulsations, and splinter hemorrhages. The lateral gaze palsy is a non-localizing sign caused by stretching of the sixth cranial nerve.

B) INCORRECT:

A pale retina with a cherry-red spot is the pathognomonic finding for central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). CRAO is an ophthalmologic emergency that manifests with sudden, profound, and painless monocular vision loss. This clinical picture is inconsistent with this patient's subacute, progressive headache, nausea, and transient visual obscurations.

C) INCORRECT:

Neovascularization (new, abnormal blood vessel growth) and hard exudates (lipid deposits) are hallmark features of advanced diabetic retinopathy. Although obesity is a risk factor for type 2 diabetes mellitus, no history of diabetes is provided. Moreover, this patient's primary symptoms of headache and cranial nerve palsy are not typical of diabetic retinopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Arteriovenous nicking and copper wiring are typical features of chronic hypertensive retinopathy. Although this patient's blood pressure is mildly elevated, it is not high enough to be the primary cause of her significant neurologic symptoms. Furthermore, these retinal changes develop over years of poorly controlled hypertension and do not align with the subacute onset of her headache and vision changes.

E) INCORRECT:

An increased cup-to-disc ratio, or "cupping," indicates a loss of optic nerve fibers and is the characteristic finding in glaucoma. Although chronic, untreated papilledema can eventually lead to secondary optic atrophy and cupping, it is not the typical acute finding in elevated intracranial pressure.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation suggests idiopathic intracranial hypertension, a condition of elevated intracranial pressure without an identifiable cause that is common in young, obese women.
